content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Adrian Santos: I was born in the Philippines, but I moved to the United States when I was five years old. My family settled in New England, specifically in Boston, where I've lived ever since. Growing up, I was raised by my parents in a tight-knit household. Both of my parents are highly educated—my father earned a graduate degree in engineering, and my mother has a graduate degree in education. They always emphasized the importance of education and hard work, which shaped a lot of my values. I was a pretty quiet kid, always more interested in books and puzzles than in playing outside. I remember my mother reading to me every night, and my father would often sit with me after school to help with my homework. I didn't have a lot of money growing up, but we never lacked for love or support. I went to public school in Boston, and I was always a good student, though I wasn't the most outgoing. I think that's why I gravitated toward subjects like math and science—they were predictable, and I could always count on them to make sense. I eventually earned a bachelor's degree in computer science from a local university, which led me to my current job as a software developer. I've never been married and don't have any children, but I've always been close with my parents and siblings. Life hasn't been without its challenges, but I've always tried to stay focused on what I can control—like my work, my education, and my faith. I'm a Protestant, and I've been active in my church community since I was a teenager. It's been a big part of my life, giving me a sense of purpose and belonging.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Adrian Santos: Yes, there was a moment that really shaped my path. I was in my junior year of high school, and I had the opportunity to apply for a summer internship at a local tech company. At the time, I was still pretty unsure about what I wanted to do with my life. I had always been good at math and science, but I didn't see myself as someone who would end up in tech. My parents encouraged me to apply, and I did. The process was nerve-wracking—I had to go through interviews and even a coding test. I was really nervous because I didn't have much experience, but I told myself that if I didn't try, I'd always wonder what could have been. I got the internship, and it was eye-opening. I saw how technology could solve real problems and make people's lives better. That experience solidified my interest in computer science, and I decided to major in it in college. It wasn't an easy road—there were times when I felt overwhelmed, especially as one of the few students from a non-traditional background in my program. But I kept pushing forward, and I'm grateful for that moment because it led me to where I am today.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Adrian Santos: I think it was a conscious choice, but not in the way you might expect. I wasn't one of those people who suddenly had a 'lightbulb moment' and knew exactly what they wanted to do. It was more of a gradual realization. I remember sitting in that internship, watching my coworkers solve complex problems and build something that had a real impact, and I thought, 'This is the kind of work I want to be doing.' I made a decision then to commit to it, even though I didn't know all the details of what that would look like. I had to actively choose to pursue computer science in college, to take on challenges that scared me, and to push past the doubts that came with being in a field where I was often the only one who looked like me. So, yes, it was a choice—but it wasn't a single moment. It was a series of small, deliberate steps that added up over time.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Adrian Santos: Absolutely. In fact, I think that support made all the difference. My high school had a mentorship program through a local nonprofit that connected students with professionals in various fields. I was paired with a software engineer who had immigrated from the Philippines, just like me. He didn't just talk about his career—he shared his struggles, his doubts, and how he navigated a field that wasn't always welcoming to people like us. His guidance gave me the confidence to apply for that internship, and later, to stay committed to my studies. I also had professors in college who took the time to mentor me, even when I wasn't the most outspoken student. They saw potential in me and pushed me to step out of my comfort zone. So, while I made the choice to pursue this path, I wouldn't have had the courage or clarity to do it without the support of others who believed in me.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Adrian Santos: I don't have a partner or children right now, but my family has always been the cornerstone of my life. My parents are still living in the same house we grew up in, and we're very close. My father is retired now, but he still keeps busy with community projects, especially ones that involve education and technology. My mother runs a small tutoring center for kids in our neighborhood, which is something she's always been passionate about. I visit them often, and we still have that routine of sitting down for dinner together, even if it's not every night. I also have two younger siblings—one is a nurse in California, and the other is a teacher in New York. We keep in touch regularly, and I always make it a point to attend family gatherings whenever I can. While I've never been married, I've never felt like I was missing out on anything. My life has been full in other ways—through my work, my faith, and the relationships I've built with my family and friends. I think the most important thing is that I've always known where I belong, and that's with the people who have supported me from the beginning.

Going through those interview questions brought back a lot of memories and made me reflect on how far I've come. It's interesting to look back at my childhood and see how the values my parents instilled in me—like the importance of education and hard work—have shaped the person I am today. The internship in high school was a pivotal moment that set me on the path to becoming a software developer, and I'm grateful for the support I received from mentors and professors along the way. Even though I haven't followed the traditional path of marriage or having children, my family has always been the foundation of my life, and I'm content with the life I've built through my work, faith, and relationships. It's comforting to know that the choices I made, even the small ones, have led me to where I am now.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Adrian Santos: My immediate family includes my parents, my two siblings, and my grandmother, who still lives with us. She's in her late seventies now, and while she's not as active as she used to be, she's a source of wisdom and strength for our family. She's the one who taught me how to cook my favorite Filipino dishes, like adobo and sinigang, and she always reminds me of the importance of family traditions. Even though she doesn't speak English as fluently as my parents do, she's always been a big part of my life. I remember growing up, she would sit with me after school and help me with my math homework, even though she didn't understand the concepts herself. She would just encourage me, saying, 'You're smart, Adrian. You just have to keep trying.' That kind of support meant the world to me, and I still feel her presence in everything I do. She's not just a part of my family—she's a part of who I am.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Adrian Santos: Outside of my family, there are a few friends and colleagues who have been really important to me over the years. One of them is Maria, a fellow software developer I met in college. We bonded over our shared interest in coding and our backgrounds as first-generation immigrants. She's been a great friend and even helped me through some of the more challenging times in my career. Then there's my pastor, Father Thomas, who has been a spiritual guide and a mentor in my church community. He's always been there to offer advice, whether it's about work, life, or just having a good conversation over coffee. I also have a few close friends from my high school days who I still keep in touch with, even though we've all gone different paths. They remind me of who I was and how far I've come. While I don't have a romantic partner right now, I've never felt lonely because I've always had a strong support system of friends and mentors who believe in me and my journey.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Adrian Santos: I live in a neighborhood in Boston that's a mix of old and new—there are historic buildings with red brick facades sitting right next to modern apartments with sleek glass windows. It's in the Beacon Hill area, which is known for its cobblestone streets and rich history. I've lived on Beacon Street for several years now, and I've come to love the quiet charm of the place. There are a lot of families here, and the community feels tight-knit, which is something I really appreciate. I often walk to work, and I enjoy the sense of history that surrounds me. There are also a few small cafes and bookstores nearby, which are perfect for a quick coffee break or a quiet afternoon with a book. I've gotten to know some of my neighbors over the years, and while I'm not one for big social gatherings, I do enjoy the sense of belonging that this neighborhood gives me. It's a place where I can feel at home, both literally and figuratively.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Adrian Santos: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. Beacon Hill has a quiet, almost old-world vibe that makes you feel like you're in a place where people look out for one another. I've never had any issues with crime or anything like that. The streets are well-lit, and there's always someone around—whether it's a neighbor walking their dog or a shopkeeper chatting with passersby. I think part of it is the sense of community that's still strong here. People know each other, and there's a kind of unspoken respect that comes with that. I've lived here for a while now, and I've never felt the need to worry about my safety the way I might in a more crowded or unfamiliar area. It's one of the things I really appreciate about this neighborhood—it gives me peace of mind, which is important when you're just trying to live your life and focus on your work.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Adrian Santos: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the positive side, I love the sense of history and the quiet pace of life. It's a neighborhood where you can walk outside without needing to rush, and there's always something interesting to see or learn. The local bookstores and cafes are like little sanctuaries where I can recharge, and I've made some good friends through community events and church activities. But it's not without its challenges. The cost of living here is pretty high, and sometimes it feels like the rent is eating up a big chunk of my paycheck. I've had to be careful with my budget, especially since I'm not making a huge salary yet in my field. There are also times when I feel like I'm not fully part of the community in the way some of my neighbors are—some of them have been here for generations, and I'm still figuring out my place in this city. But I think that's part of the journey. I'm still learning, still growing, and I'm grateful for the stability and opportunities this neighborhood has given me.

Going through the questions about my family and neighborhood made me reflect on how much my roots and environment have shaped who I am. Talking about my parents, siblings, and grandmother reminded me of the strong foundation they've given me, and how their support has been essential in every step of my journey. When I discussed my current neighborhood, it felt like I was sharing a part of my daily life that I often take for granted—the quiet streets, the sense of community, and the peace of mind that comes with living somewhere safe and familiar. It's interesting how these topics brought up not just facts, but feelings—of gratitude, belonging, and the small joys that make life meaningful. I realized that even though I've built my life around work and faith, it's the people and places I've known all along that have truly grounded me.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Adrian Santos: A typical week for me is pretty structured, though there's always some flexibility depending on work deadlines or church events. I usually wake up around 7 a.m., have a quick breakfast, and then head into the office. My job as a software developer can be pretty demanding, so I try to stay focused during the day. I work from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., but sometimes I have to stay late if there's a project that needs wrapping up. On days when I'm not working late, I like to take a walk around Beacon Hill in the evening—it's peaceful, and I enjoy the way the lights reflect off the cobblestone streets. On weekends, I like to visit my parents or spend time with my grandmother. We often cook together, and she always insists on making her famous adobo. I also try to attend church services on Sundays, which gives me a chance to connect with the community and reflect on my faith. There are also times when I'll meet up with friends or go to a local café to catch up. It's not always perfect, but I think this rhythm has helped me find balance in my life—between work, family, and the things that truly matter to me.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Adrian Santos: I work as a software developer for a mid-sized tech company that specializes in creating educational software for schools and universities. My job is pretty demanding, but I enjoy the challenge of solving complex problems and seeing the impact of my work. I typically work a standard 9-to-5 schedule, though I often find myself working a little later in the week, especially when we're launching a new product or fixing a critical bug. I'm based in the office most days, but I do have the option to work remotely a few days a week, which I appreciate because it gives me some flexibility. My role involves writing code, collaborating with other developers, and sometimes meeting with clients to understand their needs. I've been in this position for about three years now, and while it's not always easy, I feel like I'm growing both professionally and personally. It's a job that keeps me busy, but I also make sure to set aside time for the things that matter most—like family, faith, and the simple joys of life.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Adrian Santos: Outside of work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. I've always been into reading, especially science fiction and history—those are my go-to genres when I want to unwind. I try to read at least a chapter a night before bed, which helps me relax after a long day. I also enjoy cooking, especially experimenting with Filipino recipes, though my grandmother's adobo is still the gold standard. I've been trying to get better at baking, which is something I never really mastered growing up. On the weekends, if I'm not visiting family, I like to take long walks or go to the local library. I find that being around books and quiet spaces helps me reflect and recharge. And of course, I make time for my faith—whether it's attending church services or just taking a few minutes each morning to pray or meditate. These little habits, the reading, the cooking, the walking, the praying—they all add up to a life that feels balanced and meaningful to me.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Adrian Santos: One recent change to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I used to just rush through my coffee and get ready for work, but I've started taking a few minutes to sit in silence, breathe deeply, and center myself before the day begins. It's something I learned from a friend who's a yoga instructor, and it's made a noticeable difference in how I approach my work and interactions with others. I also started going to a local fitness class a couple of times a week—it's a small group that meets in a community center nearby, and it's been a nice way to stay active and meet new people. I think these small changes, while not dramatic, have helped me feel more present and in control of my life. It's funny how sometimes the simplest adjustments can have the biggest impact over time.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Adrian Santos: I don't have children of my own, but if I did, I imagine their days would be pretty structured, especially during the school year. They'd probably wake up early, have a quick breakfast, and head off to school. After school, they'd likely have some time for homework, followed by extracurricular activities—maybe sports, music, or something like coding clubs if they showed an interest in that. I think it's important for kids to have a balance between academics and play, so I'd want to make sure they had time to explore their passions. On the weekends, we'd probably go to the park, visit family, or maybe even try out a new recipe together. While I haven't had the experience of raising children myself, I've seen how my siblings and friends have approached it, and I admire the dedication and love it takes to raise a family. I think the most important thing would be to provide them with a stable, supportive environment where they feel safe to grow, learn, and be themselves.

Going through the recent interview topics made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the people and places I've known. Talking about my family reminded me of the deep roots I have in my parents, siblings, and grandmother—each of them has played a role in who I am today. My neighborhood, Beacon Hill, feels like home, and even though it has its challenges, it offers a sense of safety and community that I truly value. My daily routine, with its balance of work, family, and personal time, helps me stay grounded. I've also been making small changes to my life, like incorporating mindfulness and fitness into my mornings, which have helped me feel more present and in control. It's amazing how these seemingly small aspects of life—my routines, my environment, and the people around me—add up to create the life I live now. I'm grateful for the stability, the support, and the little joys that make it all meaningful.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Adrian Santos: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm generally in good shape, though I've had my share of ups and downs over the years. I've always been pretty active as a kid, mostly because I was always studying or working on puzzles, which kept my mind sharp but didn't do much for my physical fitness. It wasn't until a few years ago that I realized I needed to take better care of my body. I started going to the gym more regularly, and I've made an effort to eat healthier—though I still have a sweet tooth for Filipino desserts like halo-halo, which I can't resist. I also try to get enough sleep, which is something I used to neglect when I was working long hours or dealing with deadlines. I've been dealing with some mild back pain from sitting at a desk for most of the day, so I've started incorporating more stretching and yoga into my routine. I also make sure to visit my doctor for regular check-ups, and I take my medications as prescribed when needed. Overall, I feel like I'm on the right track, and I'm learning to listen to my body more. Health is something I didn't think about much in my younger years, but now I see it as an important part of living a balanced and fulfilling life.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Adrian Santos: For me, staying healthy has become easier as I've started to see it as part of my daily routine rather than something I have to force myself to do. What makes it easier is having small, consistent habits—like waking up a little earlier to stretch, eating more whole foods, and making time for exercise even if it's just a short walk around the neighborhood. I also find that staying connected with my faith and taking time to reflect or pray in the morning helps me feel more centered, which in turn makes it easier to make healthier choices throughout the day. What makes it harder, though, is the occasional slip-up—whether it's skipping a workout because I'm tired or giving in to that extra slice of cake at a family gathering. I've learned to be kind to myself when that happens, though. I think the key is balance, and I'm still learning what that looks like for me. It's not about perfection, but about making choices that support my overall well-being, even on the days when I don't feel like it.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Adrian Santos: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some recurring lower back pain, which I think is largely due to the long hours I spend sitting at my desk. It started as a mild discomfort, but over time, it's become more frequent, especially after long workdays. I've been seeing a physical therapist once a week, and they've been helping me with exercises to strengthen my core and improve my posture. I also started using a standing desk a few months ago, which has made a noticeable difference. There was one point where I had to take a short break from work to focus on my recovery, but I'm slowly getting back on track. It's been a reminder that my health is something I can't ignore, and I'm learning to be more proactive about it. I've also started incorporating more stretching into my routine, and I've found that taking short walks during the day helps me stay more alert and less stiff. It's not perfect, but I'm grateful for the support of my therapist and the small changes that have helped me feel better.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Adrian Santos: Honestly, my back pain hasn't really interfered with my work or my ability to care for my family, which I'm grateful for. I've had to make some adjustments, like taking more frequent breaks during the day or using ergonomic tools at my desk, but I've been able to manage it without major disruptions. I think the biggest challenge has been learning to listen to my body and not push through the pain when I need to rest. At first, I was worried that this kind of issue would hold me back, but instead, it's taught me the importance of self-care and balance. I've also become more mindful of how my work habits affect my health, which has led me to make some positive changes in how I structure my day. It's not always easy, but I've come to see it as part of the journey—something that reminds me to slow down, take care of myself, and not take my health for granted.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Adrian Santos: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of growth and reflection. Professionally, I've taken on more responsibility at work, which has been both challenging and rewarding. I've been leading a small team on a new project, and while it's been stressful at times, it's also given me a sense of accomplishment that I didn't expect. On a personal level, I've been working on finding more balance in my life—between work, family, and my own well-being. I've been more intentional about spending time with my parents and grandmother, and I've noticed how much that has enriched my life. I've also been trying to be more present in the moment, whether it's during a walk in Beacon Hill or while cooking with my grandmother. There have been moments of doubt, especially when I feel like I'm not making enough progress in my career or when I'm overwhelmed with responsibilities, but I've also learned to be kinder to myself and to recognize the small victories along the way. Overall, I feel like I'm moving in the right direction, even if it's not always smooth sailing.

Going through the recent interview topics made me reflect on how much my health and daily habits have shaped my overall well-being. It's interesting how small changes, like incorporating mindfulness into my mornings or taking short walks during the day, have had a meaningful impact on how I feel both physically and mentally. I used to overlook the importance of health, but now I see it as an essential part of living a balanced life. The back pain I've been dealing with has been a reminder to be more proactive about my body and to make adjustments that support my long-term wellness. I've also come to appreciate the role of routine in maintaining that balance—whether it's through exercise, healthy eating, or simply taking time to breathe and center myself. It's amazing how these small, consistent choices add up to create a more grounded and fulfilling life, even when things don't always go perfectly.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Adrian Santos: I think I've been fortunate in that I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in the way some people do, but I've had my moments of feeling overwhelmed or uncertain, especially during times of transition. There was a period a few years ago when I was juggling a demanding job, family responsibilities, and personal goals, and I felt like I wasn't doing enough in any of them. It wasn't clinical, but it was a feeling of being stretched thin, of not having enough time or energy to give everything the attention it deserved. I've learned to recognize those feelings for what they are—not as signs of failure, but as signals that I need to slow down, take a step back, and prioritize what truly matters. I've also found that talking to friends, going to church, and even just taking a walk in the neighborhood have helped me reset and regain perspective. I think the key has been learning to be gentle with myself and to accept that life doesn't always have to be perfect to be meaningful.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Adrian Santos: For my family, the past year has been one of quiet strength and support. My parents have been doing well—my father has been volunteering with a local tech education initiative, which keeps him engaged and fulfilled, and my mother continues to run her tutoring center, helping kids in our neighborhood with their studies. My grandmother, though she's been slowing down a bit, has been a constant source of comfort and wisdom. She still finds joy in small things, like watching the seasons change or sharing stories from her youth. My siblings and I have stayed close, even with the distance between us. My sister in California recently visited for a few weeks, and we spent a lot of time reminiscing about our childhood, which was both nostalgic and grounding. My brother in New York has been busy with his teaching job, but he makes it a point to call or video chat regularly. Overall, I feel grateful that my family has remained a steady presence in my life, offering love and support even as we all navigate our own paths. They've always been my foundation, and I know I can always count on them.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Adrian Santos: For me, religion has always been a source of strength and guidance. Being Protestant, I've been active in my church community since I was a teenager, and it's been a cornerstone of my life. It's not just about attending services or following rules—it's about finding purpose, connection, and a sense of belonging. My faith has helped me through difficult times, whether it was navigating the challenges of being a first-generation immigrant, dealing with self-doubt in my career, or simply feeling overwhelmed by the pace of life. I find comfort in knowing that there's something bigger than myself, and that gives me a sense of peace. My church has also been a place where I've made lifelong friendships and found mentors who have supported me in both spiritual and practical ways. Even on days when I'm not sure about everything, I know I can turn to my faith for guidance, and that has been a constant in my life.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Adrian Santos: I don't use social media very often, to be honest. I've always been more of a private person, and I find that platforms like Facebook or Instagram can be overwhelming with all the noise and comparison. I do keep in touch with family and a few close friends through messaging apps, but I don't spend a lot of time scrolling through feeds or engaging with content online. My church community has a small group chat where we share updates and events, and that's about as much as I need. I think I've always preferred face-to-face interactions or even a simple phone call over the impersonal nature of social media. There are moments when I wonder if I'm missing out on something, but I've come to realize that my life is full in other ways—through my work, my family, and the quiet moments that matter most. I don't feel the need to be constantly connected to the wider world through these platforms.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Adrian Santos: Honestly, I don't rely on social media for emotional or financial support during tough times. I've always found that the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, and my church community—are more than enough. When I'm going through something difficult, I reach out to them directly, whether it's through a phone call, a visit, or even just a quiet conversation at church. I think there's something about face-to-face connection that social media can't really replace. That said, I do appreciate the way social media can be a tool for staying informed or connecting with others who share similar interests, but I've never felt the need to use it as a crutch. I've always believed that the support I need is already around me, and I'm grateful for that.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25 made me reflect on how my health and mental well-being have shaped my daily life and sense of balance. It's been a journey of learning to listen to my body, especially with the recurring back pain I've been dealing with, and realizing that self-care is just as important as work or family responsibilities. I used to overlook the importance of health, but now I see it as an essential part of living a balanced and fulfilling life. The small changes I've made—like incorporating mindfulness into my mornings, taking short walks, and being more intentional about rest—have had a meaningful impact on how I feel physically and mentally. I've also come to appreciate the role of routine in maintaining that balance, whether it's through exercise, healthy eating, or simply taking time to breathe and center myself. It's amazing how these small, consistent choices add up to create a more grounded and fulfilling life, even when things don't always go perfectly. I've also learned to be kinder to myself during moments of doubt or overwhelm, recognizing that life doesn't have to be perfect to be meaningful. Overall, these reflections have helped me gain a deeper understanding of how my health and well-being are intertwined with the other aspects of my life, and I'm grateful for the support of my family, friends, and faith that have helped me along the way.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Adrian Santos: In the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have been more manageable, largely because I've been more intentional about how I handle challenges. I used to carry a lot of things on my own, thinking that showing weakness was a sign of failure. But I've learned that it's okay to ask for help, whether it's from my parents, my friends, or even my pastor. I've also started using journaling as a way to process my thoughts and emotions—it helps me clarify what's on my mind and gives me a sense of control. I've found that taking short breaks during the day, even just a few minutes to breathe or stretch, makes a big difference in how I feel. I've also been more mindful of my thoughts, trying not to let small worries spiral into bigger anxieties. It's not always easy, but I've come to see stress as something that can be managed, not something that defines me. I'm learning to be more patient with myself and to trust that, even when things feel overwhelming, I have the strength to keep going.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Adrian Santos: In terms of making ends meet, my monthly budget is pretty tight but manageable. My biggest expenses are rent, which takes up a significant chunk of my paycheck, and groceries, especially since I try to cook most of my meals at home. I also have regular expenses for utilities, internet, and transportation, which includes my car payment and gas. I've been trying to be more mindful of my spending, like cutting back on dining out or unnecessary subscriptions. I also set aside a small amount each month for savings, even if it's just a few hundred dollars—it's a habit I've been working on to build some financial security. My parents don't ask for much, but I do try to contribute to their household expenses when I can, like helping with groceries or covering some of their bills when they need it. It's not always easy, especially with the high cost of living in Boston, but I've learned to prioritize what's essential and find ways to stretch my budget without sacrificing the things that matter most to me.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Adrian Santos: My household spending last month was around $3,200, which is pretty much in line with what I usually spend each month. The bulk of that goes to rent—my apartment in Beacon Hill is comfortable but not cheap, and it's one of the few things I can't really negotiate. Groceries come next, especially since I try to cook most of my meals at home, and I like to have some variety, even if it means splurging on fresh produce or specialty ingredients for Filipino dishes. Utilities and internet are also a regular expense, and I've been trying to be more mindful of my energy usage to keep those costs from creeping up. Transportation is another fixed cost—I drive an older car that I keep maintained, and gas prices have been a bit of a challenge lately. I also set aside a small amount for savings, even if it's just a few hundred dollars a month, because I've learned that financial security is something you build over time. There are also occasional expenses, like gifts for my parents or my grandmother, or going out for a meal with friends, but those are more of a bonus than a necessity. Overall, I've gotten pretty good at managing my budget, and while it's not always easy, I know that I'm living within my means and prioritizing what truly matters to me.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Adrian Santos: We rent our home. I've been living in the same apartment on Beacon Street for about four years now. It's a small two-bedroom unit, but it's cozy and has everything I need. The rent is definitely one of the biggest expenses, but I've come to appreciate the convenience of living in a safe, familiar neighborhood. I actually moved here right after college, and it felt like the natural next step—staying close to my family, being near my church, and having a place that felt like home. I don't see myself buying a house anytime soon, mostly because of the high cost of real estate in Boston and the fact that I enjoy the flexibility of renting. Plus, I like the idea of being able to move if the right opportunity comes along, whether it's a job change or just wanting to explore a different part of the city. For now, this place works for me, and I'm grateful for the stability it provides.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Adrian Santos: Over the past year, my bills have had their usual ups and downs, depending on the season and what's going on in my life. In the winter, my utility bills—especially heating—go up, which is something I've had to budget for. I also noticed that during the holidays, I tend to spend a bit more on gifts for my parents and grandmother, which adds to the overall cost. On the flip side, during the summer, my electricity usage goes down, and I save a bit on cooling costs since the apartment isn't too big. There were also a few months when I had to pay for additional medical expenses related to my back therapy, which wasn't in my original budget. I've learned to adjust my spending throughout the year, setting aside a little extra in the months leading up to the winter to cover the higher heating costs. It's not always perfect, but I've gotten better at planning ahead and making small adjustments to keep things in balance.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my family and faith have supported me through life's challenges. Talking about my family reminded me of the strength and love that has always been there for me, even as we all navigate our own paths. My parents, siblings, and grandmother have been my foundation, offering unwavering support and wisdom. My faith has also been a constant source of comfort and guidance, helping me find purpose and peace, especially during times of uncertainty or stress. I've come to appreciate how much I rely on these relationships and beliefs, rather than on social media or external validation, to get through tough times. It's reassuring to know that I don't need to seek emotional or financial support from online platforms when I already have a strong, real-life support system. These reflections have deepened my gratitude for the people and values that shape my life, and I feel more grounded knowing that I can always turn to them for strength and connection.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Adrian Santos: I do save, though it's not always a large amount. I have a savings account where I try to put away at least a few hundred dollars each month, even if it means cutting back on small luxuries or dining out less often. I've learned that saving, even in small increments, gives me a sense of security and control over my finances. I also try to be mindful of my spending habits, like tracking my expenses using a simple spreadsheet I made myself. It's not about having a lot—it's about being prepared for the unexpected, whether it's a medical expense, a car repair, or just a rainy day. I remember when I first started working, I didn't save much at all, and that taught me the hard way how important it is to have a financial cushion. Now, I see saving as part of my responsibility to myself and my family, even if it's just a small step forward each month.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Adrian Santos: For me, saving in the last year has been more about preparing for the unexpected rather than a specific big purchase like a home. I've been focusing on building a small emergency fund that can cover a few months of essential expenses if something were to happen—like an unexpected medical bill or a sudden job change. I also set aside a little bit each month for personal goals, like traveling or taking a course to improve my skills in software development. I know I'm not saving a huge amount, but I've come to see it as a way to give myself peace of mind. It's not about having everything, but about knowing that I'm not completely unprepared for life's surprises. I've learned that even small, consistent savings add up over time, and that gives me a sense of control and responsibility over my future.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Adrian Santos: My occupation is software developer, and it's a role that keeps me both challenged and fulfilled. As a software developer, my primary responsibilities involve designing, coding, and maintaining software applications that are used by schools and universities to enhance their educational offerings. The most important activities in my job include writing clean, efficient code, collaborating with other developers and designers, and working closely with clients to understand their needs and ensure the software meets their expectations. I also spend a lot of time debugging and testing to make sure everything runs smoothly. One of the things I enjoy most about this work is seeing how the software I help create makes a real difference in people's lives—whether it's helping teachers manage their classrooms more effectively or giving students access to better learning tools. It's not always easy, especially when dealing with tight deadlines or complex problems, but I find satisfaction in knowing that my work contributes to something bigger than myself. I've also learned that being a good developer isn't just about technical skills—it's about communication, patience, and the ability to adapt to new challenges. That's why I've always valued the mentorship I've received from others in the field, and I try to pass that same support on to junior developers when I can.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Adrian Santos: I usually work around 40 to 45 hours a week, depending on the project timeline and how much overtime we're pulling. Most weeks, it's a standard 9-to-5, but there are times when we're launching a new feature or fixing a critical bug that requires staying late. I've gotten used to it, though I try to set boundaries so I don't burn out. On average, I spend about 8 hours a day in the office, with some time spent in meetings, coding, and collaborating with my team. I also make sure to take lunch breaks and go for short walks during the day to stay refreshed. It's a demanding job, but I enjoy the challenge and the impact it has on education. I've learned to manage my time well, and I try to leave work at work so I can be fully present with my family and faith when I'm not at my desk.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Adrian Santos: No, I haven't had more than one job or business. I've been focused on my career as a software developer since I graduated from college, and while I've taken on a few side projects—like helping a local nonprofit build a website or mentoring students interested in tech—those have been more of a passion project than a full-time commitment. I think part of that comes from wanting to stay focused on my main role, especially since the demands of software development can be pretty intense. I also value the stability that my current job provides, and I don't want to stretch myself too thin. That said, I do enjoy the occasional challenge of taking on something new, even if it's just for a few weeks. It keeps me engaged and reminds me why I got into this field in the first place—to solve problems and make a difference, even in small ways.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Adrian Santos: In total, my household made around $5,200 in the past month. That includes my salary as a software developer, which is the main source of income, and a small part-time gig I've taken on with a local nonprofit where I help with some coding projects on weekends. While it's not a huge amount, it's enough to cover my rent, groceries, utilities, and a few other expenses. I also set aside a portion of that income for savings, which I've come to see as an essential part of my financial plan. I know it's not extravagant, but it's stable, and I'm grateful for the opportunities I have to provide for myself and contribute to my family when I can.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Adrian Santos: I've been at my current job for about three years now, and it's been a journey of growth and learning. The company offers a good set of benefits, including health insurance that covers me and my parents, which is something I really appreciate given our family situation. We also get paid time off, which includes vacation days, sick leave, and a few personal days. I've used those days to take short trips with my family or to recharge when I need to. One of the things I like most about the workplace is the culture—it's collaborative, and there's a real emphasis on supporting each other, especially when we're working on complex projects. The company also offers some professional development opportunities, like attending conferences or taking online courses, which I've taken advantage of to keep my skills sharp. While the job can be demanding, the benefits and the sense of community here have made it a place where I feel valued and supported.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Adrian Santos: My relationships at work are pretty positive overall. I have a good rapport with my manager, who I've come to respect both professionally and personally. He's someone who leads by example and always encourages us to think creatively and take ownership of our projects. I appreciate that he's approachable and willing to listen, even when we're facing tight deadlines or tough technical challenges. As for my coworkers, I'd say we have a strong sense of camaraderie. We've been through a lot together—late nights, last-minute fixes, and the occasional frustration—but there's a real sense of mutual support. I've formed close friendships with a few of them, and we often grab lunch or coffee together. It's not just about working well together; it's about knowing that you can rely on each other when things get tough. I think that kind of environment makes a big difference, especially in a field like software development, where the work can be isolating if you're not careful. I feel lucky to be part of a team that values collaboration and treats each other with respect.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Adrian Santos: My work schedule is pretty predictable, though there's some flexibility depending on the project. Most days, I follow a standard 9-to-5 routine, but I do have the option to work remotely a couple of days a week, which I appreciate. The company encourages a healthy work-life balance, so I'm not expected to be in the office every single day. That said, there are times when we're working on tight deadlines or launching a new product, and those weeks can be a bit more unpredictable. I've learned to manage my time well, and I try to leave work at work so I can be fully present with my family and faith when I'm not at my desk. It's not always easy, but I think the flexibility helps me stay grounded and focused on what truly matters.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Adrian Santos: Overall, I feel pretty stable about my financial situation. It's not extravagant, but it's enough to cover my needs and provide for my family when I can. I know that I'm not making a huge salary, especially compared to some of my peers in the tech industry, but I've come to accept that my income is tied to the value I bring to my work and the opportunities I've had. I've also learned to be mindful of my spending and to prioritize what truly matters—whether it's saving for the future, supporting my parents, or enjoying the simple things in life. I don't have a lot of debt, and I've been able to build a small emergency fund, which gives me a sense of security. I know there's always room for growth, and I'm working on improving my financial literacy so I can make better decisions in the long run. For now, I'm content with where I am, knowing that I've made the most of the opportunities I've been given and that I'm on a path that allows me to live with dignity and purpose.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40 made me reflect on how my financial stability and work-life balance have shaped my sense of security and purpose. These reflections have deepened my gratitude for the balance I've found between work, family, and personal well-being, and I feel more in control of my future than I ever have before.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Adrian Santos: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up. My father was a civil engineer, and my mother was a teacher. They both worked full-time, though my mother often took on extra hours during the school year to support our family. I remember how dedicated they were—my father would come home exhausted from long days at the office, but he would still sit down with me to help with my homework, and my mother would make sure I had dinner ready before she went to her evening classes or meetings. They never complained about the long hours or the stress, but I could tell it wasn't easy. They always made it clear that education was the key to a better life, and they worked hard to give me and my siblings the opportunities they didn't have when they were younger. Looking back, I realize how much sacrifice they made, and it's one of the reasons I've always valued hard work and education so much. Their example shaped the way I see my own career and responsibilities, and I'm grateful for the foundation they gave me.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Adrian Santos: My father worked as a civil engineer, and his most important activities involved designing and overseeing infrastructure projects—everything from bridges to public transportation systems. He was very detail-oriented and had a strong sense of responsibility, which I think came from growing up in a family that valued education and hard work. He would often take me to job sites when I was younger, and I remember watching him sketch blueprints or talk to contractors about materials and timelines. It wasn't always easy for him, especially when dealing with tight deadlines or unexpected challenges, but he always approached problems with a calm, methodical mindset. My mother, on the other hand, was a teacher—she taught high school mathematics, and her most important duties involved not only instructing students but also mentoring them and helping them prepare for their futures. She had a way of making even the most complex math problems seem simple, and she always encouraged her students to think critically and ask questions. I remember her staying late after school to help students who were struggling, and she would often bring work home with her, even on weekends. Both of them had demanding jobs, but they always made time for their family, and that taught me the importance of balance and dedication.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Adrian Santos: My father worked for a government agency that handled infrastructure development, and my mother was employed by a public school district. My father's work involved a lot of planning, design, and oversight of construction projects—sometimes he was out in the field, sometimes in an office reviewing blueprints or meeting with city officials. It was a stable job, but it came with long hours and a lot of responsibility. My mother, on the other hand, worked directly with students, and her job was more about shaping young minds than building structures. She taught high school math, and she had a way of making even the most difficult concepts seem approachable. Both of them were dedicated to their work, but they also made sure that their family came first. I remember how my father would bring home reports and blueprints, and my mother would bring home lesson plans and student work. They didn't always have a lot of money, but they always made sure we had what we needed—books, school supplies, and the kind of support that helped me believe in myself and my future.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Adrian Santos: Looking a few years ahead, I hope to continue growing in my career as a software developer, maybe even take on more leadership roles or mentor others who are just starting out in the field. I also hope to be more financially stable, so I can contribute more to my parents' household and maybe even help my siblings with their own goals. I want to keep living in Beacon Hill because it's a place that feels like home, and I hope to see more of my neighborhood thrive and stay the kind of community that supports people like me. On a personal level, I hope to continue deepening my faith and staying connected with my family, even as life keeps moving forward. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I do know that I want to keep living with purpose, gratitude, and the same values that my parents taught me—hard work, education, and the importance of family. I hope to be someone who not only builds software but also builds connections, supports others, and finds joy in the simple, meaningful things in life.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Adrian Santos: What I value the most in my life is the sense of connection—whether it's with my family, my faith, or the people I work with. My parents taught me that relationships are the foundation of everything, and I've carried that lesson with me throughout my life. I value the quiet moments, like sitting down for dinner with my parents or sharing a cup of coffee with a friend, because those are the times when I feel most grounded. I also value the opportunity to grow, both professionally and personally. My work gives me a sense of purpose, but it's the people around me—the ones who have supported me, challenged me, and believed in me—that make life meaningful. I value gratitude, too. Even on the days when things feel overwhelming, I try to remember the small joys—the sound of my grandmother's voice, the smell of adobo cooking in the kitchen, the peace of walking through Beacon Hill at sunset. These are the things that remind me why I keep going, and they're what I hope to carry with me no matter where life takes me.

It also made me think about how my job as a software developer, while demanding, provides the income and benefits I need to support my family and maintain a stable life. The predictability of my work schedule, the flexibility to work remotely, and the positive relationships I've built with my manager and coworkers all contribute to a sense of stability that I didn't take for granted before. I've come to appreciate the small victories in my financial life, like saving a few hundred dollars each month or adjusting my spending to cover seasonal changes. These reflections have deepened my gratitude for the balance I've found between work, family, and personal well-being, and I feel more in control of my future than I ever have before.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection and gratitude. It's amazing how much my roots—my family, my faith, and the values instilled in me from a young age—have shaped the person I am today. From my childhood in Boston, raised by parents who prioritized education and hard work, to the pivotal moment of that high school internship that set me on the path to becoming a software developer, each chapter of my life has led me to where I am now. I've come to appreciate the support of mentors, friends, and my church community, who have been instrumental in my growth and resilience. Living in Beacon Hill, with its sense of history and community, has given me a place to call home, even as I navigate the challenges of a demanding career and personal health. My financial journey, while not extravagant, has taught me the value of balance, saving, and mindful spending. And looking ahead, I hope to continue growing in my career, supporting my family, and staying true to the values that have always guided me. This reflection has reminded me that life is not just about the big moments, but also the small, consistent choices and relationships that build a meaningful and grounded existence.
